prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum and H2D+/N2H+ observations of six evolved cores

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Technical Justification
We will observe the continuum emission from six dense cores in ALMA's Band 7, using single pointings with a resolution of 0.25" (30 AU at 120 pc). This resolution has been chosen to best resolve substructure in the cores, including small (~ 50 AU) accretion disks, larger (~few hundred AU) pseudodisks, and fragmentation into multiple features. With this resolution, we will be sensitive to structures up to 7" scales, or ~800 AU. Because the cores are highly concentrated (either in interferometer millimetre continuum or in NH3 line emission; see Figure 3) we are confident that single pointings will recover the small-scale structure we are interested in probing, and that we have selected the central position of each core as the pointing phase centre.
The continuum emission will be observed using two 1.875 GHz spectral windows at 358 GHz and 360 GHz, respectively, for a total continuum bandwidth of 3.75 GHz. We will further observe simultaneously H2D+ 1_10 - 1_11 at 372.4 GHz and N2H+ 4-3 at 372.7 GHz, using spectral windows of 234.375 MHz bandwidth and 122 kHz spectral resolution (0.098 km/s at 372 GHz). From our Cycle 0 observations, this resolution will be sufficient to resolve the lines and allow robust spectral modelling.
The required sensitivity in Band 7 is driven by the H2D+ observations. Toward SM1N, we find a peak H2D+ line temperature of 1.3 K in a 1.5" beam, greater than the single dish line brightness at the same location (see Figure 2). The observed line widths are ~0.5-0.6 km/s (FWHM). Near the Oph B2-A7 core (~ 10" offset), which is similar in mass to most of the targeted cores, single-dish H2D+ observations show line strengths of ~0.3 - 0.5 K (Friesen et al. 2010). We thus require a sensitivity of 0.1 K in velocity channels of 0.15 km/s resolution. This can be achieved in 18 minutes integration per pointing, for a total Band 7 time request of 4.06 hours. In this time, we will obtain a sensitivity of 0.09 mJy in a 0.25" beam in the continuum, sufficient to detect well the expected core structures.
We use a second science goal to set up additional, single-pointing observations of CO 2-1 (230.5 GHz) at 0.75" angular resolution (90 AU). The CO spectral window will have a bandwidth of 468.8 MHz and spectral resolution of 244 kHz (0.3 km/s). We will further smooth to 0.8 km/s spectral resolution to improve sensitivity, while retaining sufficient velocity resolution to detecting outflows near young sources. Based on detections of outflows around FHSC candidates (e.g., Dunham et al. 2011), we require a sensitivity of 0.15 K per 0.8 km/s channel to detect outflows, which can be achieved in 15 minutes per source, for a total Band 6 time request of 2.77 hours. In this time, we will obtain a sensitivity of 0.04 mJy/beam in the continuum, which will give, e.g., a S/N ratio of ~40 for SM1N assuming typical dust properties.
Any detected CO outflows may have flux unresolved by ALMA in this configuration without the ACA, but we are most interested in a) identifying protostellar sources through the presence of outflows, and b) using the observed outflow size scales to place limits on the dynamical age of the embedded sources. For FHSCs, for example, slow outflows of ~2-3 km/s would reach size scales of ~ 400-600 AU in 1000 years. Single pointings, without the ACA, will achieve these goals. Three additional 2 GHz bandwidth spectral windows will be used to observe the continuum, and will be used to determine the spectral index of the continuum emission between the Band 6 and Band 7 observations.
The total time request for this proposal is therefore 4.06 hours (Band 7) and 2.77 hours (Band 6), or 6.83 hours total.

Technical Justification
We will observe the continuum emission from six dense cores in ALMA's Band 7, using single pointings with a resolution of 0.25" (30 AU at 120 pc). This resolution has been chosen to best resolve substructure in the cores, including small (~ 50 AU) accretion disks, larger (~few hundred AU) pseudodisks, and fragmentation into multiple features. Three additional 2 GHz bandwidth spectral windows will be used to observe the continuum, and will be used to determine the spectral index of the continuum emission between the Band 6 and Band 7 observations.
The total time request for this proposal is therefore 4.06 hours (Band 7) and 2.77 hours (Band 6), or 6.83 hours total.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe with ALMA six centrally concentrated, highly evolved starless cores in the cluster-forming Ophiuchus molecular cloud. The selected targets include cores both within and outside of the larger Oph filaments. Despite their highly concentrated single-dish submillimetre features and small-scale structure as probed by interferometric NH3 observations, 70 micron non-detections indicate that any embedded protostars are very low luminosity, with upper limits L_int < 0.1 L_Sun for most of the targets. The proposed observations will reveal the core structure at 0.25" resolution (30 AU) at 359 GHz continuum, and the core kinematics using the dense gas tracer H2D+, critical to identify rotation and infall in the dense gas. Finally, we will search for slow outflows potentially driven by embedded first hydrostatic cores or extremely young embedded protostars undetected at 70 micron.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00396.S - Friesen, R., First Interferometric H2D+ Observations Toward a Protostellar and Starless Core
